title: Which is correct: 'Synonymous to' or 'Synonymous with'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the A2A. This is an example of a preposition error question. They are widely recognized as errors and even tested for on the SAT. Though imho they are unnecessary, they’re important to know. Preposition errors can be categorized as idiom errors. An idiom is simply the way we say things because it’s the way we say things. This makes it particularly difficult to learn for non-native speakers, while native speakers learn it intuitively because they hear it the same way over and over again their entire lives. For example, you always “insist on” something never “insist to” something, even though in many cases “to” would be more intuitive. And sometimes they are even context-dependent, for example, you agree with a person, but you agree to a proposal. So how will you be able to identify these preposition idioms in the future? Most online dictionaries will include several sample sentences that can help. So let’s use this approach to tackle your question. Here’s an online dictionary entry for the word synonymous. Scroll past the definition and related forms to example.  I highlighted each case where there was a preposition after the word synonymous. As you can see it is always used with the preposition “with.” If I was copyediting a piece that said “synonymous to,” unless it was a non-standard usage, I would correct it to “synonymous with.” I hope that helps.

The correct collocation would be “Synonymous with” as shown below: The Connecticut Republican brand was once synonymous with moderation. If history had been kinder, their name might have been equally synonymous with the computer revolution. This has led some scientists to predict the extinction of wines that are nearly synonymous with the liquid itself, such as Burgundy’s pinot noirs or Bordeaux clarets. That tradition, Warren says, is near-synonymous with hazing. Pumpkins are synonymous with fall, whether that means carving them or cooking them. I hope this helps.
